posts.name: Brett
posts.cooked: Hey yall, I’m the CAD lead for 5826 and for the last year Ive been super interested in the design and function of frc turrets. Although we would probably never do a turret in season due to their complexity, I’ve been really inspired by 3255’s 2024 turret and the tennis launcher and would love to get some tips on how to cad a turret and how to make it sturdy enough to remain consistent. Any advice would be great!

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked:
In a (week or so? hopefully?) 2910 will post their CAD, and they’re an example of a very successful turret robot from this year. might be beneficial to dive into that CAD when it comes out, though that’s at the higher end of complexity.

We ran a turret this year, but it was on the simpler end of things. if you have any specific questions about our turret or how the theory of them works, feel absolutely free to ask me. however it’s kind of difficult to give general advice on how to CAD a turret because, of course, it depends on what you’re trying to do. A turret used on a bot from this year, for example, would most likely be VERY different from a turret used on a bot from 2022.

Would strongly suggest researching into 971 2022 and 254 2019 (they have info in cad/build threads). Our turret from this year (public cad) is heavily based on these. Note these are for turrets that require being able to take good amounts of weight/force and a turret for a game like 2021 would be different.

posts.name: Pizzatc
posts.cooked: I was just about refer to 6036 or 2910’s turrets but both you guys beat me to it

posts.name: Peyton Yeung
posts.cooked:
Here’s a pretty recent thread that might have the kind of information you’re looking for.

Help with designing turret

posts.name: Brett
posts.cooked: I would love to hear more about what things you guys did to make it robust in the real world. We had a lot of difficulty making a complex and robust design and I’d like to hear more about how you guys did it!

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked:
The standards such as Loctite, shimming gears, and other things like this all apply heavily to turrets to reduce backlash. Some things that we didn’t do great with our turret this year that are things to improve on were: The turret base itself was too small. The bearing we used was too small to encompass our whole shooter, which meant we couldn’t run it super fast without risk of it breaking. So for you guys, make sure the turret is reasonably sized to support your turret application. The bolts holding the bearing assembly together were also too small, leading to the possibility of them backing out and letting our turret get “decapitated” which happened in port Hueneme. After we resized them, we had no issues. So for you guys, make sure bolts that are under load in your turret are able to take that load well.

Hope this helps, feel free to ask any questions

posts.name: Eli Uva
posts.cooked:
We have posted CAD for our 2024 robot as well as tennis launcher on our GrabCAD if that could be of any help! They a both based on Greyt turret from West Coast Products but uses a 10DP gear instead. Let me know if you have any questions
